description.other_contributors: Koray Atalag, University of Auckland, New Zealand
Silje Ljosland Bakke, Bergen Hospital Trust, Norway
Lars Bitsch-Larsen, Haukeland University hospital, Norway
Einar Fosse, National Centre for Integrated Care and Telemedicine, Norway
Heather Grain, Llewelyn Grain Informatics, Australia
Luis Marco Ruiz, Norwegian Center for Integrated Care and Telemedicine, Norway
Ian McNicoll, freshEHR Clinical Informatics, United Kingdom (Editor)
Anoop Shah, University College London, United Kingdom
John Tore Valand, Helse Bergen, Norway

details.purpose: *To record detail about a symptom - either self-recorded by an individual or recorded on the behalf of a patient by a clinician. A complete patient history may include varying level of details about a variety of symptoms.(en)
details.use:
*Use to record detailed information about a symptom as told to a clinician by a patient or self-recorded by the individual/patient.
This archetype allows a 'nil significant' statement to be explicitly recorded.(en)
details.misuse:
*Not to be used to record details about pain. Use the specialisation of this archetype - the CLUSTER.symptom-pain instead.
Not to be used for diagnoses and problems that form part of a persisting Problem List - use EVALUATION.problem_diagnosis.(en)

details.purpose:
To record details about a single symptom as reported by an individual, parent, care-giver or other party.
A complete patient history may include varying level of details about a multiple symptoms.
details.use:
Use to record detail about a single symptom as reported by an individual, parent, care-giver or other party. It may be recorded by a clinician as part of a clinical history record as reported to them, or self-recorded as part of a clinical questionnaire or personal health record.
This archetype has been designed as a generic framework for all symptoms.
It is intended to be inserted into the 'Details' SLOT within the OBSERVATION.story archetype or in any other ENTRY or CLUSTER archetype requiring capture of symptom-related data. It can also be reused by inserting it within other CLUSTER.symptom archetypes - within either the context of the 'Associated symptoms' SLOT or 'Previous details' SLOT. The specific symptom will be identified by the value for the 'Symptom name' data element, preferably from a selected terminology where available.
The use of 'Not present' in clinical data recording reflects an efficient way for clinicians to explicitly record that a symptom is not causing the patient any discomfort or disturbance, usually without any necessary qualifers or reasons. The possibility of modelling of 'Not present' as an a separate exclusion CLUSTER or ELEMENT archetype within the Symptom archetype, in the same way as 'No examination done' has been modelled within examination CLUSTER archetypes, has been deliberately avoided because of additional, unwarranted overheads to model maintenance, implementation and querying. For these pragmatic reasons 'Not present' has been included as an explicit data element in this Symptom archetype.
Specific data elements that are uniquely and additionally required for the identified symptom can be included as a separate CLUSTER archetype inserted into the 'Specific Details' SLOT. For example, those required to record details about pain.
Some data elements will have values sets that are in common with all symptoms, for example Severity values as Mild, Moderate and Severe. Others, such as 'Impact' will require unique value sets that are relevant to the identified symptom, for example the functional impacts of hearing loss will be significantly different to pain.
details.misuse:
Not to be used for recording objective observations of a physical or mental disturbance in the body of an individual - use OBSERVATION.exam and related examination CLUSTER archetypes for this purpose.
Not to be used for diagnoses and problems that form part of a persisting Problem List - use EVALUATION.problem_diagnosis.

details.purpose: *To record detail about a symptom - either self-recorded by an individual or recorded on the behalf of a patient by a clinician. A complete patient history may include varying level of details about a variety of symptoms.(en)
details.use:
*Use to record detailed information about a symptom as told to a clinician by a patient or self-recorded by the individual/patient.
This archetype allows a 'nil significant' statement to be explicitly recorded.(en)

details.purpose: For registrering av detaljer om et symptom - enten registrert av personen selv eller registrert på vegne av pasienten av en klinikker. En fullstendig anamnese kan inkludere forskjellige nivåer av detaljer om forskjellige symptomer.
details.use:
Anvendes til registrering av detaljert informasjon om et symptom som det fortelles til en klinikker eller selv-registrert av personen selv.
Denne arketype tillater spesifikk registrering av et "null signifikant" utsagn.
details.misuse:
Skal ikke anvendes til registrering av detaljer om smerter. Bruk den spesialiserte -the CLUSTER.symptom-pain arketype istedet.
Anvendes ikke til diagnoser og problemstillinger der er en del av den eksisterende Problem list - bruk EVALUATION.problem_diagnosis.

translations.author: University of Heidelberg, Central Queensland University
Jasmin Buck, Sebastian Garde
lbla@helse-bergen.no
Haukeland University Hospital of Bergen, Norway
Lars Bitsch-Larsen
translations.accreditation: MD, DEAA, MBA, spec in anesthesia, spec in tropical medicine.

items.items: *Symptom(en)
*A subjective observation of a physical or mental disturbance in the body of an individual.(en)
*Symptom name(en)
*The symptom experienced by the subject of care.(en)
*Symptom name should be coded with a terminology, where possible.(en)
*Description(en)
*Narrative description of the symptom as perceived by the subject of care.(en)
*Variation(en)
*The variation of the symptom during its course since onset.(en)
ثابت
العرض موجود بشكل ثابت/مستمر
متقطع
العرض موجود في بعض الأوقات و غائب في البعض الآخر
متموج
العرض يتغير بشكل مؤثر و لكنه موجود في جميع الأوقات
*Effect(en)
*Perceived outcome after exposure of the variable on the symptom.(en)
*Modifying Factor(en)
*Detail about how a specific factor impacts the symptom.(en)
*Factor(en)
*Name of an activity which might impact on the symptom.(en)
*Examples of activities: lying on multiple pillows, eating or administration of medication.(en)
*Severity(en)
*The overall intensity of the symptom as reported by the individual.(en)

*Defining values such as mild, moderate or severe in such a way that is applicable to multiple symptoms plus allows multiple users to interpret and record them consistently is not easy. To extend the value set further with inclusion of additional values such as 'Trivial' and 'Very severe', and/or 'Mild-Moderate' and 'Moderate-Severe', adds to the definitional difficulty and may also worsen inter-recorder reliability issues. Use of 'Life-threatening' and 'Fatal' is also often considered as part of this value set, although from a pure point of view it may actually reflect an outcome rather than a severity. In view of the above, keeping to a well-defined but smaller list is preferred. Note: more specific grading of severity can be recorded using the 'Specific details' SLOT.(en)
*Mild(en)
*The intensity of the symptom does not cause interference with normal activity.(en)
*Moderate(en)
*The intensity of the symptom causes interference with normal activity.(en)
*Severe(en)
*The intensity of the symptom causes prevents normal activity.(en)
*Visual analogue score(en)
*Rating scale for severity of the symptom.(en)
*Symptom severity can be rated by the individual by recording a score from 0 (symptom not present) to 10.0 (symptom is as severe as the individual can imagine).(en)
*Duration(en)
*The duration of the symptom since onset.(en)
*If 'Date/time of onset' and 'Date/time of resolution' are used in systems, this data element may be calculated, or alternatively, considered redundant.(en)
*Number of previous episodes(en)
*The number of times this symptom has previously occurred.(en)
*Not present(en)
*The individual has not experienced the symptom.(en)
*Record as True if the subject of care has not experienced the symptom.(en)
*Course description(en)
*Narrative description about the course of the symptom since onset.(en)
*For example: a text description of the immediate onset of the symptom, activities that worsened or relieved the symptom, whether it is improving or worsening and how it resolved over weeks.(en)
*Description(en)
*Narrative description of the effect of the modifying factor on the symptom.(en)
*Description of previous episodes(en)
*Narrative description of any or all previous episodes.(en)
* May include a comparison to this episode.(en)
*Associated symptoms(en)
*Structured details about any associated symptoms that are concurrent.(en)
*Previous episode(en)
*Structured details of the symptom during a previous episode.(en)

*In linked clinical systems, it is possible that previous epsiodes are already recorded within the EHR. Systems can allow the clinician to link to relevant previous episodes. In an unlinked system or with a new patient, no previous episodes will be available and additional instances of the symptom archetype could be used to record the previous episodes. (en)
*Detailed anatomical location(en)
*Slot to contain detailed and structured anatomical location details.(en)
*If the anatomical location is included in the Symptom name via precoordinated codes, use of this SLOT becomes redundant.(en)
*Anatomical location(en)
*Record of a simple site on the body where the symptom was located.(en)

*Occurrences for this data element are unbounded to allow for clinical scenarios such as describing a pain in multiple locations but where all of the other attributes such as impact and duration are identical. If the requirements for recording the body site are determined at run-time by the application or require more complex modelling such as relative locations then use the CLUSTER.anatomical_location or CLUSTER.relative_location within the Detailed anatomical location' SLOT in this archetype. If the anatomical location is included in the Symptom name via precoordinated codes, this data element becomes redundant.(en)
*Date/time of onset(en)
*The timing of the onset for this episode of the symptom.(en)
*While partial dates are permitted, the exact date and time of onset can be recorded, if appropriate.(en)
*Specific details(en)
*Specific data elements that are additionally required to record as unique attributes of the identified symptom.(en)

*For example: description of pain can require additional data elements describing the radiation and visual analogue rating scales; description of sore throat may include presence of fever or rigors, and difficulty swallowing.(en)
*Associated events(en)
*Structured details about any associated symptoms that are concurrent.(en)
*Impact(en)
*Description of the functional impact of this symptom.(en)

*Assessment of impact should consider the severity, duration and frequency of the symptom. Examples for hearing loss may include: 'Difficulty Hearing in Quiet Environment'; 'Difficulty Hearing the TV or Radio'; 'Difficulty Hearing Group Conversation'; and 'Difficulty Hearing on Phone'.(en)
*No effect(en)
*Presence of the factor has no impact on the symptom.(en)
*Precipitates(en)
*Presence of the factor causes onset of the symptom.(en)
*Worsens(en)
*Presence of the factor exaccerbates the severity or impact of the symptom.(en)
*Relieves(en)
*Presence of the factor reduces the severity or impact of the symptom.(en)
*Date/time of resolution(en)
*The timing of the cessation of this episode of the symptom.(en)

*If 'Date/time of onset' and 'Duration' are used in systems, this data element may be calculated, or alternatively, considered redundant. While partial dates are permitted, the exact date and time of resolution can be recorded, if appropriate.(en)
*Resolves(en)
*Presence of the factor resolves the symptom.(en)
*Comment(en)
*Additional narrative about the symptom not captured in other fields.(en)
Symptom
A subjective observation of a physical or mental disturbance in the body of an individual.
Symptom name
The symptom experienced by the subject of care.
Symptom name should be coded with a terminology, where possible.
Description
Narrative description of the symptom as perceived by the subject of care.
Variation
The variation of the symptom during its course since onset.
Constant
The symptom is constantly present.
Intermittent
The symptom is present at times and not at others.
Fluctuating
The symptom varys considerably but is almost always present.
Effect
Perceived outcome after exposure of the variable on the symptom.
Modifying Factor
Detail about how a specific factor impacts the symptom.
Factor
Name of an activity which might impact on the symptom.
Examples of activities: lying on multiple pillows, eating or administration of medication.
Severity
The overall intensity of the symptom as reported by the individual.

Defining values such as mild, moderate or severe in such a way that is applicable to multiple symptoms plus allows multiple users to interpret and record them consistently is not easy. To extend the value set further with inclusion of additional values such as 'Trivial' and 'Very severe', and/or 'Mild-Moderate' and 'Moderate-Severe', adds to the definitional difficulty and may also worsen inter-recorder reliability issues. Use of 'Life-threatening' and 'Fatal' is also often considered as part of this value set, although from a pure point of view it may actually reflect an outcome rather than a severity. In view of the above, keeping to a well-defined but smaller list is preferred. Note: more specific grading of severity can be recorded using the 'Specific details' SLOT.
Mild
The intensity of the symptom does not cause interference with normal activity.
Moderate
The intensity of the symptom causes interference with normal activity.
Severe
The intensity of the symptom causes prevents normal activity.
Visual analogue score
Rating scale for severity of the symptom.
Symptom severity can be rated by the individual by recording a score from 0 (symptom not present) to 10.0 (symptom is as severe as the individual can imagine).
Duration
The duration of the symptom since onset.
If 'Date/time of onset' and 'Date/time of resolution' are used in systems, this data element may be calculated, or alternatively, considered redundant.
Number of previous episodes
The number of times this symptom has previously occurred.
Not present
The individual has not experienced the symptom.
Record as True if the subject of care has not experienced the symptom.
Course description
Narrative description about the course of the symptom since onset.
For example: a text description of the immediate onset of the symptom, activities that worsened or relieved the symptom, whether it is improving or worsening and how it resolved over weeks.
Description
Narrative description of the effect of the modifying factor on the symptom.
Description of previous episodes
Narrative description of any or all previous episodes.
May include a comparison to this episode.
Associated symptoms
Structured details about any associated symptoms that are concurrent.
Previous episode
Structured details of the symptom during a previous episode.

In linked clinical systems, it is possible that previous epsiodes are already recorded within the EHR. Systems can allow the clinician to link to relevant previous episodes. In an unlinked system or with a new patient, no previous episodes will be available and additional instances of the symptom archetype could be used to record the previous episodes.
Detailed anatomical location
Slot to contain detailed and structured anatomical location details.
If the anatomical location is included in the Symptom name via precoordinated codes, use of this SLOT becomes redundant.
Anatomical location
Record of a simple site on the body where the symptom was located.

Occurrences for this data element are unbounded to allow for clinical scenarios such as describing a pain in multiple locations but where all of the other attributes such as impact and duration are identical. If the requirements for recording the body site are determined at run-time by the application or require more complex modelling such as relative locations then use the CLUSTER.anatomical_location or CLUSTER.relative_location within the Detailed anatomical location' SLOT in this archetype. If the anatomical location is included in the Symptom name via precoordinated codes, this data element becomes redundant.
Date/time of onset
The timing of the onset for this episode of the symptom.
While partial dates are permitted, the exact date and time of onset can be recorded, if appropriate.
Specific details
Specific data elements that are additionally required to record as unique attributes of the identified symptom.

For example: description of pain can require additional data elements describing the radiation and visual analogue rating scales; description of sore throat may include presence of fever or rigors, and difficulty swallowing.
Associated events
Structured details about any associated symptoms that are concurrent.
Impact
Description of the functional impact of this symptom.

Assessment of impact should consider the severity, duration and frequency of the symptom. Examples for hearing loss may include: 'Difficulty Hearing in Quiet Environment'; 'Difficulty Hearing the TV or Radio'; 'Difficulty Hearing Group Conversation'; and 'Difficulty Hearing on Phone'.
No effect
Presence of the factor has no impact on the symptom.
Precipitates
Presence of the factor causes onset of the symptom.
Worsens
Presence of the factor exaccerbates the severity or impact of the symptom.
Relieves
Presence of the factor reduces the severity or impact of the symptom.
Date/time of resolution
The timing of the cessation of this episode of the symptom.

If 'Date/time of onset' and 'Duration' are used in systems, this data element may be calculated, or alternatively, considered redundant. While partial dates are permitted, the exact date and time of resolution can be recorded, if appropriate.
Resolves
Presence of the factor resolves the symptom.
Comment
Additional narrative about the symptom not captured in other fields.
*Symptom(en)
*A subjective observation of a physical or mental disturbance in the body of an individual.(en)
*Symptom name(en)
*The symptom experienced by the subject of care.(en)
*Symptom name should be coded with a terminology, where possible.(en)
*Description(en)
*Narrative description of the symptom as perceived by the subject of care.(en)
*Variation(en)
*The variation of the symptom during its course since onset.(en)
Dauerhaft
das Symptom ist dauerhaft anwesend
Zeitweise
das Symptom ist abwechselnd anwesend und nicht anwesend
Variabel
das Symptom variiert deutlich, ist aber praktisch ständig anwesend

Konstant
Symptomet er konstant tilstede.
Intermitterende
Symptomet er tilstede tidvis og fraværende til andre tider.
Fluktuerende
Symptomet varierer betydelig, men er tilstede nesten hele tiden.
